PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What It Was," and No. 2, entitled "Pioneers' Life," are still being compiled. If you have already answered these, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health
( ) Pioneer birth and death
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Presentation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Sanford Broadhead - farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 25th, 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   Linwood and Bethel, Minnesota
   1880 - 1898
   1898 - 1905

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 25 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Desire to get rich quick, war my husband's reason. My desire was to leave the cyclonic wind storms behind me. Minnesota is a very wooded state and noted for high velocity winds.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

Tucker, Mrs. Susan

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child.")

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

"I came west because I knew the climate would be more suitable for me. We needed a way to make a living."

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

"I learned about the West through friends who had already moved there."
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought we were crazy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? By ourselves - husband, wife and four children.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railroad - and here they are in a descent.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.). A former school boy met me at Crack Lock, and we were driven in a democrat behind a spirited team down into what looked like the depths of Hell - just at even tide. This turned out to be Beaver Creek valley. We ended up that night - mother, father and our four children at a brother's former neighbor, one-room shack. There was only bunk bed, with the children about six while my husband and I slept in a back parlor. It was an unforgettable night.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We slept and lived in a two-room house, had windowless shack. If I'd had the money and opportunity I would have returned to the States. The prospectors really got us alive, and the children had to walk.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Crack Lock.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Green Brier, Lock - May 1910

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Store keeper. We farmed. Cows, chickens and pigs, and baked bread for tileless bachelors.

Never in my life, before or since, have I experienced such a feeling of well-being, all's right with the world as I would when my Dad signed the bill and said "Everybody back to bed." Stern's all over.

As if of one accord, we came to life, some of us diving head-first into the apple barrel, others plunging our arms to the elbows in the dill pickle crock, searching for the biggest pickle. Up the stairs we would climb, laughing and joyfully spill milk to the water pail and with peace and contentment in our hearts—falling into bed—perhaps to dream of finding the old dill pickles and potatoes with great big juicy green eyes.

As I sit here and listen to the roar of the bulldozer as it excavates our new, big, up-to-date, modern community deep freeze storage locker plant, I feel sad, sad that my children's children will never have memories of the old food cellar, remember so vividly—and the delicious—my mother prepared from the contents therein.

I wonder, as I roast my perfectly preserved, frozen-in-a-minute, big, juicy, tender corned beef, if future, will my family enjoy it as much as we enjoyed the corned beef and cabbage preserved so well in the old storm cellar? I wonder—oh, yes, I wonder,

The Old Storm Cellar

With the roar of a bull-dozer and the harsh grating sound of the cartage trucks ringing in my ears as they rip and tear the huge gaping hole in the earth for our new community's first freeze locker plant, I wonder; yes, I wonder how many remember it—the old storm cellar?

I remember it. I remember it well.

My parents migrated from the woody cyclone Minnesota state in the early nineteen-hundreds to the Canadian prairie.

From living in one extreme they reverted to the other, a pioneer homestead overseeing nothing but a flat expanse of prairie, nary a hill or a dale in sight.

How I, as a young one, hated that endless, bleak land with only the trees above meeting the horizon to break the view. The heat waves that rippled and shimmered in the distance on hot summer days filled me with a woebegone, desolate feeling that then unexplainable.

My parents, however, seemed to revel in that newly-found freedom of space and appreciated God's handiwork in its naked state. Nary a tree was planted on our homestead. They never ceased to be awed at the beautiful panoramas of the skies; sunsets, sunrises, the moon, the stars, rainbows, storm-clouds, sun-dogs. My folks were never earth-bound; they literally lived with their heads in the clouds. My dad, as well as his breed, delighted in the songs of the wild birds, war keys, geese, ducks of the air. How often I've heard my parents remark "Wonderful country, this Canada. Space to see and live in. No chance of a storm sneaking up and catching us unawares in this country"—No more!

My mother would often, come the cold winter evenings, hold us spellbound with true tales of her youth and homes of the far-off prairie winds that ripped and tore their way through her childhood territory, great trees snapping like match sticks; houses sailing through the sky like modern aeroplanes, barns, horses, cattle, pigs, all over single log coops, and Aunt Hattie our maiden aunt, hanging suspended by her long, beautiful hair in her nightdress, from the top of a huge oak tree. Aunt Hattie lived to tell the tale but died in her bed, partially scalped, head to her dying day.

Grandma, a pioneer nurse in her own right, bound the injured messes back on with good thick, black molasses.

Then there was cousin Tessie, who sailed through the tree tops, also in night attire, was frequently held in a neighbor's oat bin. She, poor girl, was innocent, but for years and years quite forever after, but we all loved hearing how cousin Tessie saved her wild oats.

The cellar meant that lumber was naturally an expensive commodity—and cement was virtually unknown. The roof had no fancy shingles but was covered with tar paper, lathed on. In as much as we young ones used to sleigh-ride from the roof to the ground on the banks of piled up snow, our house frequently leaked some rain on those days. But no one seemed to care overly much. At the first splash someone would run for a tin dipper. Occasionally the leak would spring unexpectedly over someone's bed and then Dad would hustle to tack on a new piece of tar paper.

Oh, I'm willing to admit our house was not as much as far as modern houses go and as the family grew, it grew room by room. But, by golly it did have one thing of which we were mightily proud: It had a storm cellar.

Most pioneer homes, I think I can safely say all pioneer homes had a cellar—an ordinary hole in the ground beneath the house garden provision cellar. No fancy affairs, these either. At least ours wasn't. A few rough boards shelves held the jars of fruit, canned vegetables such as marrow, squash, pumpkin, cabbage, etc. This was more or less temporary produce and not expected to keep more than that last fall December. We also kept a small barrel of potatoes handy here for ready daily access. Our family, like most pioneer families was a big one; ten of us boys and girls all mixed up alive and kicking, and very discontented.

Food, then as today, was of vital importance! It's true my mother's knowledge of balanced diets, vitamins and calories was nil in my early days, but she did realize, that the human frame as all, she must have healthy, happy children and not spindly, undernourished, mentally retarded ones.

Consequently, my mother and dad usually gardened in a big way and always respected a bountiful harvest. Should nature fail, we had a bountiful supply of water in the form of a deep "bucket on a rope" well. How we youngsters hated that job! We were backwards, all.

Watering the garden was our ob. At least we had to dip and carry the pails of water to the garden's edge. Mother and dad took it from there. The last one to the well was always a big, fat, monkey and no one seemed to mind it. At this job we were backwards, all.

With our own children in mind, nowadays, I shudder at the thought of what old pioneer women must have endured. If it hasn't been only a few feet from our kitchen door stood, the top of the cellar like a stick a foot or so off the ground. To each side, a two-by-four piece of lumber was nailed with nails that could sink the pail to the proper level for my slight weight. Invariably the pesky thing would disappear out of sight. Then there was to me a torturous thing—a bitter tug-o-war between the over-flowing pail on one end of the rope and me, a very disgruntled me, on the other end. One thing I can say, however, this hard over-stretching of the rope built up muscles on my forearms and a strength in my wrists, unknown to most puny females. These facts so impressed my sportsman Dad, he attempted to make a female puller just for me. He even went so far as to team me up with a brother two years older, for boxing lessons. Many a bout we've put on for the benefit of the visiting threshing crew. Mother eventually noticed my nose growing in size and leaning to one side, but put a stop to this unlady-like racket.

But in the meantime the gardens were watered, vegetables grew, the harvests were garnered and finally stored in our underground cellar and its neighbor, the风暴 cellar.

Now the storm cellar was descriptive to the same as the ordinary cellar except it led away from the ordinary cellar by a dark underground passage. Not only this, it was a bit deeper and had the floor of our house here too. It was a place under the earth, beneath the frost line with only the sky above. To me it was an awesome thing. It had two main purposes: To store and preserve the quantities of garden produce we would consume until next year's harvest, and secondly to do just what its name implies: give protection from storms.

It was an odd-smelling place, not unpleasant and quite cool during the hot summer nights. It had offensive nerves. Not since my childhood days have I smelled a smell to equal it.

My Yankee grand-parents, thinking always of their dear daughter and family, each fall would ship several barrels of apples, sorghum syrup, brown sugar and a keg or two of apple cider. These commodities, in common with mother's canned tomatoes, preserved beans, preserved hams and corned beef, plus bushels of new spuds, blended to make an aroma I'll guarantee was unknown to any other pioneer family. We had occasion to smell it often.

Come a hot, murky, clothes-stick-to-your-back kind of day, you would hear my dad and mother begin to mutter, "This heat's terrible. Sure to blow up a storm tonight. We'll have a win and a half storm tonight. So hot and sticky, a person can't breathe. Sure to have a storm tonight." And sometimes it did.

Not the kind of storms where parents had been accustomed to rain and lightning sometimes hail, but more often rainstorms. When these storms happened to burst upon us in the middle of a noon and sight we were rushed around and ushered into our trundle beds with the words, "Hurry down to the storm cellar."

The Old Storm Cellar

With the roar of a bull dozer and the sound of the earth age trucks ringing in my ears as they rip and tear at the earth, I remember it—the old storm cellar. I remember it. I remember it. I remember it.

My parents migrated from the early cyclonic Minnesota state to the Canadian prairie living in one extreme they left behind. They reverted to the other, a pioneer over someone's bed and their bed. Many but we were put up for the winter. Occasionally a tin dipper, unexpectedly dropped by a weary traveler would run into our new place. We weren't going to be the family grave yard. The heat waves that did have any thing to do with the weather were mighty proud. It had a storm cellar filled with hot, steamy days filled with hot, steamy nights.

Most pioneer life, however, seemed to be a tale of hardship and a constant battle against the elements. My parents, however, were never heard to complain. They lived literally "in the earth." Their heads in the clouds. My dad, as well as his brood, delighted in the sounds of the wind, rain, and snow. My mother was often seen smiling up at the sky during cold winter evenings, holding tales of her youth—her home of the prairie—her childhood—her memories of the prairie. Oh, I'm willing to admit our house was modest, far as most homes go; as much so as the great new grow-room by room. But, by golly it did have one thing in which we were blessed. If there was a storm cellar.

Most pioneer homes, I think, I am safely saying, all pioneer holes in the ground beneath the house, garages, cellars, whatever they may be called, there either. At least ours wasn't. A few rough boards over a stone foundation, and a few crude bins for the easily stored winter vegetables such as marrow, turnips, carrots, and even potatoes was more or less temporary produce was not expected to keep much longer than the first snows came down. This hole kept a small bin of potatoes handy here for ready daily access. Our house was a two-room affair, and our family was a big one; ten of us boys and girls all mixed up, alive and well, and very happy.

Food, then, was today, was of vital importance. It's true my mother's cooking was rather simple, but the food was always good, and she knew how to make it taste good. She was a hard worker, and her meals were always hearty and nourishing.

One day, while we were playing outside, we heard a loud noise coming from the direction of the woods. We ran to see what was happening, and found a large tree had fallen across the road. We knew we had to get out of the way quickly, so we ran back to the house and told our parents about it. They told us to stay inside until the storm passed.

That night, we heard thunder and lightning outside, and we knew we were safe inside our house. The next morning, we went outside to see the damage caused by the storm. We were amazed at the destruction caused by the wind and rain.

Our house was typical of most early pioneer dwellings. It started out being a squat two-room cabin built on a hillside, and was banked with nature's bountiful prairie soil—plain, ordinary dirt. Thirty miles by sleigh or wagon horse team to the nearest railway.

The Canadian Film Guild comes of age

Britain's oldest film society, The Edinburgh Film Guild, this year celebrates its 21st anniversary. With more than 3,500 members, it is thought to be one of the largest film societies in the world.

The guild offers a wide range of films, from classic silent movies to contemporary dramas. Members can attend screenings at local movie theaters or watch films at home via streaming services.

The guild also hosts regular events, such as film festivals and workshops, to promote the art of filmmaking. Members can participate in these events and meet other film enthusiasts.

The guild's mission is to promote the art of filmmaking and to provide a platform for independent filmmakers to showcase their work. The guild supports local filmmakers and encourages them to create unique and innovative films.

The guild's membership is open to anyone who is interested in filmmaking. Members can join for a small fee and receive a variety of benefits, including discounts on tickets and merchandise.

For more information about the guild, visit their website at www.edinburghfilmguild.org.
